comments:
I realize eclipse 3.0 is not JDK 1.5.0 - ready, however I /was/ running the IDE
over the 5.0 release candidate and had a major problem.

Unfortunately I have no clear tracking data to give you but something may sound
familiar.

I was editing some Java source file and invoked "Undo" 2 or 3 times rapidly. 
The first one seemed to generate an error -- which raised a dialog that said
something to the effect of "Can't continue because of an assert error" and
"empty assert" or something similiar -- the output of an unthorough assert
statment itself.  After dismissing the dialog, the editor took a moment to
finish "reeling" from changes it was making or attempting to make and at that
point the source had become corrupted!  -- The area around the last undo had
been put back together incorrectly and there were bits of different parts of the
file in the wrong places!

I just located the log file and found the entries.  At the end of the file, the
one that says "The command for the key you pressed failed" was actually the
first message I got when the IDE began to reel and then munge the file.  I'm 90%
sure that all of the entries for Sept 15 were part of the same launch of the IDE
(it was not restarted between any of the Sept 15 entries).  That may be helpful.

The traces are almost entirely eclipse code; however, if it were in JDK code I
would want to file a bug ASAP on the 5.0 Sun release.  If you can have a look at
this and you think it is worth telling Sun about, then please let me know and I
will file a bug report over there!


OK, I can't find a way to attach my log file.  I will include all the entries
from Sept 15 and one prior.  Here you go:

(Thanks!  - Steev.)


!SESSION Sep 14, 2004 20:33:06.937 ---------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=I200406251208
java.version=1.5.0-rc
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US

Can you reproduce this? If so, can you reproduce this using a supported VM?
Was folding enabled?

Tom, please take a look at the assertion failure.

The assertion failure happens inside the standard greedy diff algorithm that has
not changed since years, and we've never seen it hit that assertion. From that I
guess this really is a VM problem and not an issue with our code.

closing as invalid, since we do not support the mentioned VM.

(This does not mean your bug report is invalid - and please reopen if you can
reproduce this using a supported VM!).

Sun anyway in case someone over there is by chance familiar with some code for
some reason (...)

In truth it makes me a little more wigged out to know that it's an assert that's
never been hit before -- and, ~curious ;-) about what the assert is!

Thanks!
